Award.AwardTitle: Found In Transition: An Archaeology of Village Life in Siin (Senegal) Before and After Atlantic contacts (AD 1300-1700)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation support, Dr. Fran√ßois Richard and an international team of researchers will conduct two field seasons of excavations in the province of Siin (Senegal) between January 2013 and July 2014. The project is a collaborative effort combining U.S. and Senegalese archaeologists to examine the centuries immediately preceding and following the advent of Atlantic contacts in Senegal in 1444. The Atlantic era is one of the most intensely researched stretches of human history and a defining moment in Africa's past, yet it is also a relatively poorly understood period. The "transitional period" (AD 1300-1700) connecting Iron Age societies to the early centuries of global encounters is particularly obscure in West Africa. This is in part because knowledge of the period rests on a small corpus of testimonies left by European navigators, which offer a limited purview of African societies at the time of contact and say little about them before that. Archaeology can redress these difficulties, by offering empirical glimpses of the African past before the advent of documented history and generating independent evidence to complement historical records during the Atlantic era. When confronted with other sources, archaeological datasets can point to gaps or inconsistencies in historical understanding, and craft a richer portrayal of African experience.

The Siin provides a compelling point of entry into questions of historical transitions in Senegambia, the area of Africa with the longest record of contacts with Europe. Between 1300-1700, the region witnessed momentous events, involving massive population migrations, the development of a centralized kingdom, and the incorporation of the region into global circuits of exchange. Despite its small size, the Siin polity was deeply implicated in the historical processes that fashioned the Senegambian past, and its turbulent history is poised to cast critical light on the political, economic, and cultural transformations that accompanied African communities' transitions into the Atlantic era. This history has left significant material traces in the form of ancient villages and other vestiges of past social life, which are readily amenable to archaeological analysis.

To investigate the question of Atlantic transitions in Siin, the research team will gather archaeological information about the ways in which village communities negotiated transformations in regional economies. This will be implemented through large-scale excavations at two sites, Diohine (S260) located in the hinterland and Mbissel (S106) situated on the coast. These two sites were selected on the basis of initial archaeological testing, which revealed well-preserved village remains, with multiple occupations spanning the period of interest. Excavations will focus on exposing broad horizontal surfaces to reveal relations between different components of the sites. Particular attention will be given to residential contexts, trash middens, and activity areas. The goals for this phase of the project are to get a better understanding of six dimensions of village experience during the "transitional period": 1) Occupation histories and social space, 2) trade, 3) domestic and craft production, 4) consumption practices, 5) technology, and 6) ritual life. Collected artifacts (local ceramics, tobacco pipes, metal objects, stone tools, beads, imported goods), their contexts of recovery, and changing distributions over time and space will help to address these multiple questions. Specialized compositional analysis of ceramics will provide additional information about the source of pottery and its circulation. A pilot program to test the feasibility of soil chemistry data will be implimented. Collectively, these different strands of evidence will provide invaluable data on village life in Siin, given the complete absence of thorough, long-term, extensive excavation programs in the region. They will enable the compilation of village profile in the area between AD 1300 and 1700, and permit an investigation of rural trajectories in times of global entanglements. As currently planned, the first phase of the project will begin in January 2013 and consist of excavations at Diohine. The second phase will take place the following year, and move the seat of excavations to Mbissel. In both contexts, excavations will be complemented by extensive mapping within the sites' immediate peripheries. This work, which is designed to situate occupation histories in broader spatial context, will expand previous mapping and survey work conducted at the sites.

With regard to broader impacts, the study will foster new understanding about an obscure yet foundational period of African history, which has never been the object of systematic investigations in Senegal. This, in turn, will provide the basis for major revisions in historical portrayals of Senegal and Atlantic Africa, and key contributions to scholarly research on indigenous people's long-term engagement with global economic expansion. The project will also be a forum for cross-cultural collaboration and learning between Senegalese, European, and American students and professionals, and consultation with the rural communities of Siin about their past. In addition to the published materials that will come out of this research, we will also disseminate results to broader publics, and plan on staging an exhibit at the National Art Museum in Dakar.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Using archaeological research, this NSF-funded project investigates the transition to the era of Atlantic exchanges in West Africa. Much has been written about the turbulence of the Atlantic slave trade and violence of its effects in the 17th and 18th centuries. Yet our knowledge of the first 200 years of entanglements with the Atlantic economy, after Europeans made landfall in 1444, is surprisingly limited for many parts of Africa, given the paucity and unevenness of documentary archives.

 

To remedy these difficulties, this project mobilizes archaeology as a prime source of information about African history before and after the origins of the Atlantic trade. The research focuses specifically on Siin, a small province of Senegal, the country with the longest record of engagement with European expansion. We selected two sites for a comparative study: 1) A coastal location, Mbissel (site number S106), also known as the first, short-lived capital of the Siin kingdom, and 2) Diohine (site number S260), portrayed in oral traditions as one of Siin’s oldest and most conservative villages. These sites had previously been documented, and were known to have extensive village vestiges dating to the period of Atlantic transitions. Excavations took place over four seasons between 2013 and 2016, targeting a) residential contexts associated with the origins of the villages and their occupations during the Atlantic era, in order to obtain data about domestic life, and b) trash mounds, which give us key insights about what people acquired, consumed, and threw away.

 

A number of patterns has emerged from the material remains uncovered at both sites: 1) Residential history: The sites show different occupational histories. S260 was founded around AD 1000, and grew larger over the course of its history, just as the site moved from its original locus toward the northeast to blend into of the present-day village of Diohine. S106, by contrast, has a much longer history of near continuous occupation, dating back to the Neolithic. Its size appeared to ebb and flow over time; 2) Pottery: Types and decorations are relatively similar in both assemblages. However, a full analysis of vessel functions and sizes will likely reveal trends in meal consumption (say a move from smaller containers to larger communal style dishes, increase/decrease of water storage vessels, etc.). Archaeometric studies conducted on a sample of excavated ceramics provide information about vessel composition and origins, suggesting that pottery-making was small-scale and seasonal; 3) Trade items: Collections of imported objects are dominated by beads, but they are diminutive for the period of study, which hints that both areas were relatively marginal to major trading circuits before the Atlantic area and until the 18th century; 4) Metallurgy: We might have uncovered evidence of iron-smelting at S260, but the deposits were quite disturbed. A systematic examination of slags (a byproduct of iron reduction) might indicate whether the slag they derived from iron smithing or smelting. Metal objects are few, highly oxidized, and fairly non-descript; 5) Architecture/housing: Architectural technology does not seem to change much during the period of interest, nor do dwellings. This should be qualified, however, by the fact that mud walls are sensitive to decay and quickly disintegrate in the soil, making it largely impossible to determine wall direction, house shape, and dwelling size. To palliate these limitations, we collected systematic samples from cultural surfaces/floors, which we have sent out for soil chemistry analysis. Variation in chemical composition is often associated with particular types of activities, which might help us to assign closer identifications and functions to excavated spaces; 6) Fauna/flora: Excavations revealed considerable amounts of animal bones, which are currently being analyzed. Preliminary results indicate a wide-ranging diet, inclusive of most living creatures, in contrast with the food-related proscriptions observed in some areas of the western Sahel. We also expect that botanical and phytolith analyses will provide information about dietary changes in terms of plant consumption; and 7) Religious practices: One of the most interesting aspects of the study concerns the initial light it sheds on religious practices and spirituality. We encountered several inhumations, often placed in a variety of contexts: under houses, outside of dwellings, or in open areas subsequently covered by trash disposal areas. Excavations inside dwellings have also revealed certain continuities with ethnohistoric practices, such as ritual offerings similar to those associated with wrestling, and other ritual deposits reminiscent of those practiced in advance of the hunting season.

 

Overall, we have only begun to explore the available evidence of village life at our two sites, and the preliminary trends they reveal about life during the early Atlantic era. Building on the observations above, we will continue to interrogate the effects of Atlantic commerce on village communities in west-central Senegal, and the manner in which residents between the coast and the interior negotiated their relationships with cultural outsiders and globalizing markets.
